questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Intune.

You plan to manage Windows updates by using Intune.

You create an update ring for Windows 10 and later and configure the User experience settings for the ring as shown in the following exhibit.

//IMG//


Use the drop-down menus to select the answer choice that completes each statement based on the information presented in the graphic.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes Microsoft Intune.

You have an update ring named UpdateRing1 that contains the following settings:

• Automatic update behavior: Auto install and restart at a scheduled time
• Automatic behavior frequency: First week of the month
• Scheduled install day: Tuesday
• Scheduled install time: 3 AM

From the Microsoft Endpoint Manager Admin center, you select Uninstall for the feature updates of UpdateRing1.

When will devices start to remove the feature updates?

discussion.content:
Answer A
Source: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/windows-10-update-rings

When you use the Uninstall option, Intune passes the uninstall request to devices immediately.

Windows devices start removal of updates as soon as they receive the change in Intune policy. Update removal isn't limited to maintenance schedules, even when they're configured as part of the update ring.

choices.A: as soon as the policy is received
choices.D: the first Tuesday of the next month
choices.C: when a user approves the uninstall

discussion.content:
For Windows 10 devices, Microsoft Edge settings are configured using: Device configuration policy: This is because on Windows devices, Microsoft Edge is deeply integrated with the operating system. Device configuration policies in Intune allow administrators to manage various settings, including those for Microsoft Edge, at the device level. 

For both Android Enterprise and iOS/iPadOS devices, Microsoft Edge settings are configured using: App configuration policy 
App configuration policies are used for mobile devices because:
1. They allow for app-specific settings without affecting the entire device.
2. They provide a way to manage settings for Microsoft Edge as a standalone app.
3. They offer more granular control over the app's behaviour on these mobile platforms.

I think "App Configuration Policy" for all 3
Source: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/manage-microsoft-edge

Select Apps and then select App configuration policies.

On the App Configuration policies blade, choose Add and select Managed apps.

On the Basics section, enter a Name, and optional Description for the app configuration settings.

For Public apps, choose Select public apps, and then, on the Targeted apps blade, choose Edge for iOS and Android by selecting both the iOS and Android platform apps. Click Select to save the selected public apps.
